Issues.Title: Dynamic form live example: input field for "First name" is not rendered correctly
Issues.Body:
### Describe the problem that you experienced

input field for "First name" looks the same as input field for "Email" even though there is an explicit CSS rule for input[type="text"] in styles.css

Reason is that the type of QuestionBase - object is '' by default and this is assigned to the [type] of the "\<input>\" element.
"\<input type=''>\" doesn't seem right to me.

On the other hand: the correct rendering ("width: 100%") doesn't look good on a wider viewport.

1st question: should it be changed at all?

In case it should be changed my suggested solution of a pool of possible solutions is:
a) provide type-property when construction 'First name' in question.service.ts and 
d) remove or adapt CSS rule

Happy to do the PR if I know which one is the right solution for Angular.

More possible solutions:
a) provide type-property when constructing 'First name' in question.service.ts
b) add default type to question-textbox.ts
c) add default type in constructor in question-base.ts
d) remove / adapt CSS rule
e) leave it like it is (it looks good)
f) ...

### Enter the URL of the topic with the problem

https://angular.io/guide/dynamic-form

Issues.Title: ResizeObserver should be patched automatically by zone.js
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

zone.js

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

This is a follow up to #45105 and #31695, in particular the comment in https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/45105#issuecomment-1068065900: a patch for `ResizeObserver` is provided, however it is not added by default and it's presence is currently somewhat hidden in the [details of the documentation](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/2fc5b70fcedb8ac35b825b245c0ae394dc125244/packages/zone.js/README.md#bundles). One has to specifically search for it, but when using Angular it's not clear that the patched (standard) APIs may be incomplete.

In the linked issues it has been asked already why the patch is not included by default, but no answer has been given before the issues were locked automatically, hence I'm trying to reach out again to find some insights on this. The only hint I find in the docs are these lines:

https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/2fc5b70fcedb8ac35b825b245c0ae394dc125244/packages/zone.js/NON-STANDARD-APIS.md?plain=1#L239-L242

However these are clearly outdated, as all major browsers [support the API](https://caniuse.com/resizeobserver) nowadays. In fact, with the `resize` event potentially [not firing anymore for arbitrary elements](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/resize_event), the `ResizeObserver` is essential for responding to size changes, and I'd thus expect it to be quite common in use.

With the available information from the linked issues and the existing patch it should be fairly simple to enable this by default, and I can create a PR if desired. But I also wanted to verify if there is a reason for leaving it out intentionally before putting any work into it, or if it's just an oversight?

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

_No response_

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

_No response_

### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
zone-js 0.12.0, 0.11.8
```


### Anything else?

_No response_

Issues.Title: Why is webpack-bundle-analyzer strongly *not* recommended?
Issues.Body:
### Describe the problem that you experienced

For a long time, developers have been using webpack-bundle-analyzer to analyze Angular app bundle sizes. Then, at some point (Angular 9?) it came to be that webpack-bundle-analyzer was strongly discouraged by the Angular team, but other than the video below, I cannot find any official Angular documentation about it.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B-lipaiZII8&t=215s

### Enter the URL of the topic with the problem

https://angular.io/guide/deployment#inspect-the-bundles

### Describe what you were looking for in the documentation

I am looking into a clear explanation on why webpack-bundle-analyzer is strongly discouraged, in favor of source-map-explorer.

### Describe the actions that led you to experience the problem

I'm working with a custom framework which still uses webpack-bundle-analyzer in Angular versions 14-15.
On top of that, there are plenty of articles still online on how to use webpack-bundle-analyzer with Angular apps. This causes confusion (assuming there are serious reasons why we shouldn't be using it).

### Describe what you want to experience that would fix the problem

The link in the documentation mentioned above should clearly state that webpack-bundle-analyzer is not recommended, and state the reasons why.

Issues.Title: fix(core): add a type check in isCssClassMatching
Issues.Body: Small bug fix. Showing a minimum app to reproduce the bug. 1. Create the app and add angular material. ``` ng new project cd project ng add @angular/material ``` 1. Overwrite the src/app/app.component.html with minimal content. ``` ``` 1. Run the app. The button is not shown because of an exception. ``` main.ts:6 ERROR TypeError: item.toLowerCase is not a function at isCssClassMatching (core.mjs:8726:35) at isNodeMatchingSelector (core.mjs:8814:22) at isNodeMatchingSelectorList (core.mjs:8931:13) at matchingProjectionSlotIndex (core.mjs:14179:13) at Module.ɵɵprojectionDef (core.mjs:14222:49) at MatButton_Template (button.mjs:113:99) at executeTemplate (core.mjs:10534:9) at renderView (core.mjs:10356:13) at renderComponent (core.mjs:11529:5) at renderChildComponents (core.mjs:10216:9) ``` Because isCssClassMatching() function does not take care if the value is not string, while attrs[] may contain AttributeMarker which is actually numbers, item.toLowerCase() throws the exception. Just inserted a check if the item is string. ## PR Checklist Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements: - [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit - [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features) - [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features) ## PR Type What kind of change does this PR introduce? - [x] Bugfix - [ ] Feature - [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables) - [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes) - [ ] Build related changes - [ ] CI related changes - [ ] Documentation content changes - [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes - [ ] Other... Please describe: ## What is the current behavior? Issue Number: N/A ## What is the new behavior? ## Does this PR introduce a breaking change? - [ ] Yes - [x] No ## Other information

Issues.Title: Label `for` attribute will not associate to the corresponding id of an input element inside another component
Issues.Body: ### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug? core ### Is this a regression? No ### Description If I have a component with an input element inside of it, then matching that input's `id` value to a label's `for` value does not create the appropriate associations if that label is outside of the component. As an example: ``` ``` My `toggle-switch` component accepts that id as an input and places it on a `button` like this: ``` ``` According to the [HTML spec](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/forms.html#the-label-element), the preceding HTML structure should yield an association between the button and the label. Clicking the label should focus and activate the button, and the button should have an accessible label that matches the label content. That is not happening currently when the label exists outside the component. As a test, I placed the label inside the component and the appropriate association was made. ### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug _No response_ ### Please provide the exception or error you saw _No response_ ### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`) ```true Angular CLI: 14.2.10 Node: 16.13.2 Package Manager: npm 8.1.2 OS: darwin x64 Angular: 14.2.12 ... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, elements ... forms, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic ... platform-server, router Package Version --------------------------------------------------------- @angular-devkit/architect 0.1402.10 @angular-devkit/build-angular 14.2.10 @angular-devkit/core 14.2.10 @angular-devkit/schematics 14.2.10 @angular/cdk 14.2.7 @angular/cli 14.2.10 @angular/material 14.2.7 @schematics/angular 14.2.10 rxjs 7.8.0 typescript 4.6.4 ``` ### Anything else? _No response_

Issues.Title: urlUpdateStrategy: 'eager' - not working
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

router

### Is this a regression?

No (though it is possible this may have worked in a version prior to 13, which is the earliest I have tried it in).

### Description

urlUpdateStrategy: 'eager' does not appear to be working. When I navigate to a route that will throw an error, the url either stays the same as the page I was previously on, or if this page is the first to be navigates to, it goes back to the root route.

Example in stackblitz:
app.module: added { urlUpdateStrategy: 'eager' } into the RouterModule.forRoot ExtraOptions.
second.component: constructor has throw new Error('ded').

What should happen is when you click the link for "second" it should update the url to "https://angular-ivy-vurmdm.stackblitz.io/second" before it even tries to navigate (thus before it even knows there will be an error, it will already have updated the url).

What actually happens is that it seems to completely ignore the urlUpdateStrategy: 'eager' and doesn't update the url until after successful navigation, whereupon the error stops this from happening.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-vurmdm?file=src/app/app.module.ts

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
url is not updated to "second"
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Stackblitz latest version / ivy / 15.0.2

Also same problem with 13.3.0.
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "urlUpdateStrategy: 'eager' - not working" (#48881)

Issues.Title: fix(migrations): don't copy unmigrated declarations into imports array
Issues.Body:
Currently the migration is set up to assume that any elements that exist in a `declarations` array will be converted to standalone and copied into the `imports` array, however that might be incorrect for some special cases like the root component.

These changes rework the declaration merging logic so that they take all the declarations being migrated into account.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(migrations): don't copy unmigrated declarations into imports array" (#48882)

Issues.Title: Allow @Directives to have styles attached
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

core

### Description

Allow Angular `@Directive`s to attach styles the same way `@Component`s do.

I'm currently implement implementing a `@Directive` for rounding the corners of Angular Material Select.  This is a Demo:
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-cpfxig?file=src%2Fapp%2Fhello.component.css

The directive needs CSS in order to work properly.  Specifically it needs the class:
```
.el-RoundSelect
  .mat-mdc-form-field-flex
  .mdc-notched-outline
  .mdc-notched-outline__notch
  label.mdc-floating-label--float-above {
  top: 28px !important;
}
```

And it would be great if this class could be packaged with the directive.

### Proposed solution

Allow Angular `@Directive`s to attach styles the same way `@Component`s do.


### Alternatives considered

CSS can be inlined anywhere, but allowing it to be packaged with the directive keeps the design intent coherent.

### Stackoverflow

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/35915433/angular2-styles-in-a-directive
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Allow @Directives to have styles attached" (#48871)

Issues.Title: ReferenceError: Cannot access 'x' before initialization caused by missing HttpClientModule import
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

I just spent an hour researching on a __weird__ bug. I have an app with a just common lazy loaded module which uses HttpClientModule (and HttpClient). While it compiles and works locally (!), when I deploy it and go to that specific route __*nothing happens*__. I mean you click on a button but really nothing happens. There are no errors in the console either!

It's good I have a global error handler which logs all of the errors. So, I found out the error was:
> Error: Uncaught (in promise): ReferenceError: Cannot access 'P' before initialization

First, I thought I had a cyclic reference somewhere... so I checked everything and no, I didn't have it. Then I just added HttpClientModule to my module's `imports` and published the app again. Voila! It works now!

I have to add my app uses i18n, so I build it for different languages. And for default locale it works, but for others it DOES NOT.

### Proposed solution

This must be reported at least in the console. But it better be handled during compilation.

Well, it must be reported SOMEWHERE.

Angular CLI: 15.1.3
Node: 18.13.0
Package Manager: npm 9.4.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 15.1.2
... animations, cdk, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... localize, material, platform-browser
... platform-browser-dynamic, router

@angular-devkit/schematics      15.1.3
@angular/cli                    15.1.3

rxjs                            7.8.0
typescript                      4.9.4

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): support JIT compilation with esbuild
Issues.Body: When using the experimental esbuild-based browser application builder, the `aot` build option can now be set to `false` to enable JIT compilation mode. The JIT mode compilation operates in a similar fashion to the Webpack-based builder in JIT mode. All external Component stylesheet and template references are converted to static import statements and then the content is bundled as text. All inline styles are also processed in this way as well to support inline style languages such as Sass. This approach also has the advantage of minimizing the processing necessary during rebuilds. In JIT watch mode, TypeScript code does not need to be reprocessed if only an external stylesheet or template is changed.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): support JIT compilation with esbuild" (#24635)

Issues.Title: ng serve Incremental Build Times Increased Massively When Upgrading From Angular v12 -> v15
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

12.2.17

### Description

I recently tried to upgrade our large enterprise application (~1300 components) from Angular v12 to v15.  After the upgrade, I noticed that 'ng serve' incremental build times had increased from around (15s - 25s) on Angular v12 to (115s - 130s) on Angular v15. This kind of degradation in build performance was not expected.  Here are my settings in the angular.json file for our 'development' config. 

  "development": {
              "buildOptimizer": false,
              "optimization": false,
              "vendorChunk": true,
              "extractLicenses": false,
              "sourceMap": true,
              "namedChunks": true,
              "aot": false,
              "progress": true
            }

I tried a number of thing to see if I could bring down the time. One that gave a limited improvement was to move the entries from the "scripts" section in the angular.json file and directly reference them in the index.html file via script tags instead. This reduced the incremental build times to (95s - 100s) 

### Minimal Reproduction

I wasn't able to reproduce issue in a smaller application and I can't share our code base. 

### Exception or Error

_No response_

### Your Environment

```text
_                      _                 ____ _     ___
    / \   _ __   __ _ _   _| | __ _ _ __     / ___| |   |_ _|

                |___/
```

Issues.Title: Experimental @angular-devkit/build-angular:browser-esbuild and material datepicker component MAT_DATE_LOCALE bug
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

with "builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:browser"

### Description

angular 15.1.3 and angular material 14.2.7 datepicker component with @angular-devkit/build-angular:browser-esbuild shows incorrect locale

how MAT_DATE_LOCALE  should work:
https://v14.material.angular.io/components/datepicker/overview#internationalization

### Minimal Reproduction

```
npx --package @angular/cli ng new angular-datepicker --defaults
ng add @angular/material @angular/cdk
ng add @angular/material-moment-adapter
npm install http-server -g
```

app.module.ts

```
@NgModule({
    declarations: [
        AppComponent
    ],
    imports: [
        BrowserModule,
        BrowserAnimationsModule,
        MatInputModule,
        MatDatepickerModule,
        MatMomentDateModule
    ],
    providers: [
        {
            provide: DateAdapter,
            useClass: MomentDateAdapter
        },
        {
            provide: MAT_DATE_FORMATS,
            useValue: MAT_MOMENT_DATE_FORMATS
        },
        {
            provide: MAT_DATE_LOCALE,
            useValue: 'de'
        }
    ],
    bootstrap: [AppComponent]
})
export class AppModule {
}
```

app.component.ts

```
@Component({
    selector: 'app-root',
    templateUrl: './app.component.html'
})
export class AppComponent {
}
```

app.component.html

```
<mat-form-field appearance="fill">
    <input matInput [matDatepicker]="picker">
    <mat-datepicker-toggle matSuffix [for]="picker"></mat-datepicker-toggle>
    <mat-datepicker #picker></mat-datepicker>
</mat-form-field>
```

"builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:browser"
```
ng build
http-server dist/angular-datepicker
```
datepicker shows correct date format (german locale)

"builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:browser-esbuild"
```
ng build
http-server dist/angular-datepicker
```
datepicker shows wrong date format (english locale)

### Exception or Error

_No response_

### Your Environment

```text
Angular CLI: 15.1.3
Node: 18.13.0
Package Manager: npm 9.4.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 15.1.2
... animations, cdk, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... material, material-moment-adapter, platform-browser
... platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1501.3
@angular-devkit/build-angular   15.1.3
@angular-devkit/core            15.1.3
@angular-devkit/schematics      15.1.3
@angular/cli                    15.1.3
@schematics/angular             15.1.3
rxjs                            7.8.0
typescript                      4.9.4
```


### Anything else relevant?

_No response_

</details>

<details>
<summary>evanw/esbuild</summary>

### [`v0.17.5`](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#​0175)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/compare/v0.17.4...v0.17.5)

-   Parse `const` type parameters from TypeScript 5.0

    The TypeScript 5.0 beta announcement adds [`const` type parameters](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/typescript/announcing-typescript-5-0-beta/#const-type-parameters) to the language. You can now add the `const` modifier on a type parameter of a function, method, or class like this:

    ```ts
    type HasNames = { names: readonly string[] };
    const getNamesExactly = <const T extends HasNames>(arg: T): T["names"] => arg.names;
    const names = getNamesExactly({ names: ["Alice", "Bob", "Eve"] });
    ```

    The type of `names` in the above example is `readonly ["Alice", "Bob", "Eve"]`. Marking the type parameter as `const` behaves as if you had written `as const` at every use instead. The above code is equivalent to the following TypeScript, which was the only option before TypeScript 5.0:

    ```ts
    type HasNames = { names: readonly string[] };
    const getNamesExactly = <T extends HasNames>(arg: T): T["names"] => arg.names;
    const names = getNamesExactly({ names: ["Alice", "Bob", "Eve"] } as const);
    ```

    You can read [the announcement](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/typescript/announcing-typescript-5-0-beta/#const-type-parameters) for more information.

-   Make parsing generic `async` arrow functions more strict in `.tsx` files

    Previously esbuild's TypeScript parser incorrectly accepted the following code as valid:

    ```tsx
    let fn = async <T> () => {};
    ```

    The official TypeScript parser rejects this code because it thinks it's the identifier `async` followed by a JSX element starting with `<T>`. So with this release, esbuild will now reject this syntax in `.tsx` files too. You'll now have to add a comma after the type parameter to get generic arrow functions like this to parse in `.tsx` files:

    ```tsx
    let fn = async <T,> () => {};
    ```

-   Allow the `in` and `out` type parameter modifiers on class expressions

    TypeScript 4.7 added the `in` and `out` modifiers on the type parameters of classes, interfaces, and type aliases. However, while TypeScript supported them on both class expressions and class statements, previously esbuild only supported them on class statements due to an oversight. This release now allows these modifiers on class expressions too:

    ```ts
    declare let Foo: any;
    Foo = class <in T> { };
    Foo = class <out T> { };
    ```

-   Update `enum` constant folding for TypeScript 5.0

    TypeScript 5.0 contains an [updated definition of what it considers a constant expression](https://togithub.com/microsoft/TypeScript/pull/50528):

    > An expression is considered a *constant expression* if it is
    >
    > -   a number or string literal,
    > -   a unary `+`, `-`, or `~` applied to a numeric constant expression,
    > -   a binary `+`, `-`, `*`, `/`, `%`, `**`, `<<`, `>>`, `>>>`, `|`, `&`, `^` applied to two numeric constant expressions,
    > -   a binary `+` applied to two constant expressions whereof at least one is a string,
    > -   a template expression where each substitution expression is a constant expression,
    > -   a parenthesized constant expression,
    > -   a dotted name (e.g. `x.y.z`) that references a `const` variable with a constant expression initializer and no type annotation,
    > -   a dotted name that references an enum member with an enum literal type, or
    > -   a dotted name indexed by a string literal (e.g. `x.y["z"]`) that references an enum member with an enum literal type.

    This impacts esbuild's implementation of TypeScript's `const enum` feature. With this release, esbuild will now attempt to follow these new rules. For example, you can now initialize an `enum` member with a template literal expression that contains a numeric constant:

    ```ts
    // Original input
    const enum Example {
      COUNT = 100,
      ERROR = `Expected ${COUNT} items`,
    }
    console.log(
      Example.COUNT,
      Example.ERROR,
    )

    // Old output (with --tree-shaking=true)
    var Example = /* @​__PURE__ */ ((Example2) => {
      Example2[Example2["COUNT"] = 100] = "COUNT";
      Example2[Example2["ERROR"] = `Expected ${100 /* COUNT */} items`] = "ERROR";
      return Example2;
    })(Example || {});
    console.log(
      100 /* COUNT */,
      Example.ERROR
    );

    // New output (with --tree-shaking=true)
    console.log(
      100 /* COUNT */,
      "Expected 100 items" /* ERROR */
    );
    ```

    These rules are not followed exactly due to esbuild's limitations. The rule about dotted references to `const` variables is not followed both because esbuild's enum processing is done in an isolated module setting and because doing so would potentially require esbuild to use a type system, which it doesn't have. For example:

    ```ts
    // The TypeScript compiler inlines this but esbuild doesn't:
    declare const x = 'foo'
    const enum Foo { X = x }
    console.log(Foo.X)
    ```

    Also, the rule that requires converting numbers to a string currently only followed for 32-bit signed integers and non-finite numbers. This is done to avoid accidentally introducing a bug if esbuild's number-to-string operation doesn't exactly match the behavior of a real JavaScript VM. Currently esbuild's number-to-string constant folding is conservative for safety.

-   Forbid definite assignment assertion operators on class methods

    In TypeScript, class methods can use the `?` optional property operator but not the `!` definite assignment assertion operator (while class fields can use both):

    ```ts
    class Foo {
      // These are valid TypeScript
      a?
      b!
      x?() {}

      // This is invalid TypeScript
      y!() {}
    }
    ```

    Previously esbuild incorrectly allowed the definite assignment assertion operator with class methods. This will no longer be allowed starting with this release.

</details>

Issues.Title: BREAKING CHANGE: webpack < 5 used to include polyfills for node.js core modules by default. This is no longer the case. Verify if you need this module and configure a polyfill for it.
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

11.x

### Description

Installing a new package, say puppeteer (https://www.npmjs.com/package/puppeteer) and then attempting to run app using ng serve causes webpack issues.
Adding some packages which were causing an issue seems to resolve this, such as: 

`"compilerOptions": {
    "paths": {
      "path": [
        "./node_modules/path-browserify",
        "./node_modules/stream-browserify",
        "./node_modules/https-browserify",
        "./node_modules/puppeteer-core",
        "./node_modules/url"
      ]
    },`

is fine, but I keep getting errors, such as `If you want to include a polyfill, you need to:
        - add a fallback 'resolve.fallback: { "https": require.resolve("https-browserify") }'
        - install 'https-browserify'
If you don't want to include a polyfill, you can use an empty module like this:
        resolve.fallback: { "https": false }
`

Is this a problem with webpack in the angular-devkit/build-angular library?

### Minimal Reproduction

New project, (ng new project). 
Install puppeteer, npm install puppeteer.
Run ng serve.

### Exception or Error

```text
BREAKING CHANGE: webpack < 5 used to include polyfills for node.js core modules by default.
This is no longer the case. Verify if you need this module and configure a polyfill for it.

If you want to include a polyfill, you need to:
        - add a fallback 'resolve.fallback: { "https": require.resolve("https-browserify") }'
        - install 'https-browserify'
If you don't want to include a polyfill, you can use an empty module like this:
        resolve.fallback: { "https": false }

./node_modules/puppeteer-core/lib/cjs/puppeteer/node/BrowserRunner.js:71:34-58 - Error: Module not found: Error: Can't resolve 'child_process' in '/Users/wangelljames/Documents/Software/borked-invoices/node_modules/puppeteer-core/lib/cjs/puppeteer/node'
```


### Your Environment

```text
Angular CLI: 15.0.5
Node: 14.21.1
Package Manager: npm 6.14.17
OS: darwin x64

Angular: 15.1.2
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------

@angular-devkit/build-angular   15.1.3
@angular-devkit/core            15.1.3
@angular-devkit/schematics      15.0.5
@angular/cli                    15.0.5
@schematics/angular             15.0.5
```

build

"builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:browser"

Issues.Title: Angular should disable webpack's import.meta.url parsing by default
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Previously, it was noticed that when using ES modules (which Angular very much wants you to do), one cannot reference assets using `import.meta.url` (which is a web standard and really ought to work).  See: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues?q=is%3Aissue+import.meta.url+

This issue, which describes the problem well: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/22388 was closed bcause it's actually Webpack's fault and Webpack *used* to unconditionally rewrite `import.meta.url` to something useless in the absence of a loader.  But now we can stop Webpack from doing that, using the `parser.javascript.importMeta` option: https://github.com/webpack/webpack/pull/15246

... except that to do this in Angular requires a custom webpack configuration.

Since we are not supposed to have webpack-specific configuration in the angular config, it would be nice if the default behaviour of Angular was non-broken.  Obviously it would have to be done while conserving the (arguably broken and inconsistent) policy of *sometimes* using loaders and *sometimes* not using them.

### Minimal Reproduction

See https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/22388

### Exception or Error

```text
Something about not being able to access local content
```


### Your Environment

```text
Angular CLI: 15.1.2
Node: 18.12.1
Package Manager: npm 9.1.3
OS: linux x64

Angular: 15.1.1
... animations, cdk, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms

@angular-devkit/schematics      15.1.2
@angular/cli                    15.1.2
@schematics/angular             15.1.2

```

Issues.Title: Angular should *not* disable Webpack's import.meta.url parsing (for WebAssembly files, at least)
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Actually, Angular should just make up its h*cking mind (see #24616).

Currently, its mysterious and ephemeral built-in webpack configuration *disables* [module.parser.javascript.url](https://webpack.js.org/configuration/module/#moduleparserjavascripturl), so assets imported with `new URL(..., import.meta.url)` do not get packaged by default.

Okay, that's fine, if you're into that kind of thing, but at the same time it keeps [module.parser.java.importmeta](https://webpack.js.org/configuration/module/#moduleparserjavascriptimportmeta) enabled, leading webpack to output entirely useless `file://` URLs instead of doing any packaging.

End result is that you just can't use any ES6 module (such as *anything* compiled with Emscripten's `EXPORT_ES6` option) that tries to load some possibly really important asset, like, say, a WebAssembly file.  You are damned if you do and damned if you don't!  If you do what is suggested in https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/22351 and try to use the `assets` option, the actually generated code will *not* reference this asset because `import.meta.url` got rewritten to some path on your build filesystem.

But if you then disable `module.parser.java.importmeta` manually in a custom webpack config, then you end up with `import.meta.url` in the output code, which utterly breaks testing with karma (since karma does not do ES6 modules, because that's like not groovy, man) and of course also any possibility of targeting a non-ES6-aware browser.

This is the opposite of webpack's perfectly good and sane defaults.  A reasonable workaround is to create a custom webpack config which *enables* `module.parser.java.url`, like this:

```js
module.exports = {
  module: {
    parser: {
      javascript: {
        url: true,
      },
    },
  },
};
```

### Minimal Reproduction

From an Angular app, try to load an ES6 module (like https://www.npmjs.com/package/soundswallower?activeTab=explore) that has an accompanying WASM file, or any kind of asset that is loaded with `new URL(..., import.meta.url)`.  The relevant code output by Emscripten is:

```js
 wasmBinaryFile = new URL("soundswallower.web.wasm", import.meta.url).href;
```

### Exception or Error

_No response_

```text

Node: 18.12.1
Package Manager: npm 9.1.3
OS: linux x64
```

Issues.Title: Angular 15 regression: missing diagnostic on server build error
Issues.Body:
### Command

other: `ng run angular.io-example:server`

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

14.2

### Description

If an error occurs when compiling Angular for server-side rendering, the build process exits with error code 1 **without printing any diagnostic**. This makes it near impossible to figure out issues specific to SSR builds.

### Minimal Reproduction

1. Clone the [Reproduction repository](https://github.com/demurgos/angular-server-build-crash)
2. `npm install`
3. `npm build`

The repro is a stripped down variant of the official universal example. There's a syntax error on line 10 of `server.ts`. Uncommenting `from` fixes the build.

### Exception or Error

**Full output for Angular 15:**

```text
$ npm run build

> angular.io-example@0.0.0 build
> ng run angular.io-example:server

✔ Server application bundle generation complete.
$ echo $?
1
```

Full output for Angular 14.2:

```
$ npm run build

> angular.io-example@0.0.0 build
> ng run angular.io-example:server

✔ Server application bundle generation complete.

Initial Chunk Files | Names         | Raw Size

Build at: 2023-01-26T07:36:35.761Z - Hash: 2ce5cd4dbb2aca9e - Time: 6918ms

Error: server.ts:10:39 - error TS1005: 'from' expected.

10 import { AppServerModule } /* from */ './src/main.server';
                                         ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


Error: Optimization error [main.js]: SyntaxError: Unexpected token: punc ({)

$ echo $?
1
```

Issues.Title: Upgrade Library Compatibility Checker
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

upgrade

### Description

The most difficult and time consuming part of upgrading Angular is determining whether all the library dependencies are compatible. This is currently a manual process and the blockers are not discovered until late in the upgrade process after already investing significant time. A tool that automatically checks the available versions of dependencies in advance would be a huge help here!

### Proposed solution

When considering an Angular upgrade there should be a tool that examines the package.json and then examines every dependency for a peer dependency on Angular. Any such libraries should be checked for a newer version on NPM that is compatible with the target Angular version. Finally, a report should be generated showing which versions are required or which libraries are currently blocking the upgrade.

### Alternatives considered

I am unaware of alternatives.

Issues.Title: bug(mat-form-filed): padding added to mat-icon when used as a prefix/suffix does not respect density
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Any mat-icon with the matPrefix or matSuffix directive applied to it appears to always have this rule
.mat-mdc-form-field-icon-prefix>.mat-icon, .mat-mdc-form-field-icon-suffix>.mat-icon {
    padding: 12px;
    box-sizing: content-box;
}
This padding is always the same no matter what density used used for the mat-form-field. Causes form-fields to be taller then they should be when they have an mat-icon prefix/suffix and using smaller densities. Aligns the actual input at the top of the form-field.

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Set density for mat-form-field to minimum
2. Create an mat-form-field with a mat-icon as its mat-suffix

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-wxbcwr-7qsjkw?file=src%2Fapp%2Finput-prefix-suffix-example.html

The example contains 3 fields, first one uses a mat-icon-button instead of a mat-icon directly, second uses a mat-icon, 3rd wraps the mat-icon in a span.

In cases 1 and 3 no padding is applied, in the second one 12 pixels of padding is applied to the mat-icon regardless of density settings.

### Expected Behavior

Padding applied to mat-icon with a matSuffix/matPrefix directive should be adjusted based on the density of the mat-form-field

### Actual Behavior

Padding for a mat-icon with a matSuffix/matPrefix directive is always 12 pixels.

### Environment

- Angular:
- CDK/Material:
- Browser(s):
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-form-filed): padding added to mat-icon when used as a prefix/suffix does not respect density" (#26529)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-list): Badge within list item gets cut off
Issues.Body: ### Is this a regression? - [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version ### The previous version in which this bug was not present was 14 ### Description When placing a badge within a list item, the badge gets cut off: This problem has already been [mentioned before](https://github.com/angular/components/issues/12384). However, back then it was easy to apply a workaround: set `overflow: visible` or add some padding to the parent element. With the mdc migration, this has become much harder because Angular Material adds wrapping elements to list items, of which we have little control. And in v14, it works just fine, even without workaround. ### Reproduction Steps to reproduce: 1. Create a mat-(nav-)list 2. Add a badge on an element within the list StackBlitz: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-hgiusr ### Expected Behavior The badge should be fully visible ### Actual Behavior The badge gets cut off ### Environment - Angular: 15.1.0 - CDK/Material: 15.1.2 - Browser(s): Chrome 109.0.5414.87 - Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS Ventura
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-list): Badge within list item gets cut off" (#26528)

Issues.Title: fix(material/tabs): unable to click projected content in tab label
Issues.Body:
Fixes that the MDC-based tabs implementation didn't allow clicks on the projected content inside a tab, because MDC was setting `pointer-events: none`.

Fixes #26195.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/tabs): unable to click projected content in tab label" (#26527)

Issues.Title: bug(cdk/drag-drop): Incorrect "this" in method given to cdkDropListSortPredicate
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

When using cdkDropListSortPredicate to call a method in a component, "this" does not point to the component but to an object of type CdkDropList.


### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1.  Use chrome to go to the Angular docs page https://material.angular.io/cdk/drag-drop/overview#controlling-whether-an-item-can-be-sorted-into-a-particular-index
2. Open the example for "Controlling whether an item can be sorted into a particular index" in Stackblitz
3. In the method sortPredicate insert a line like 
`console.log(this.constructor.name, this.numbers);`
4. Open the developer console of Chrome
5. Drag an item of the list over another item
6. Look into developer console and check if the right class name is output

### Expected Behavior

In the method sortPredicate "this" should point to the instance of CdkDragDropSortPredicateExample, the member numbers should be defined.

The output in the console should be something like

`CdkDragDropSortPredicateExample [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8]`

### Actual Behavior

In the method sortPredicate "this" points to an object of type CdkDropList. The member "numbers" is undefined.

The output in the console is
`CdkDropList undefined`

### Environment

- Angular: 13/14/15
- CDK/Material: 13/14/15
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Linux/Ubuntu
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(cdk/drag-drop): Incorrect "this" in method given to cdkDropListSortPredicate" (#26525)

Issues.Title: fear(BUTTON): Ability to convert all double clicks on all mat-buttons (or clickable elements in general) to single click
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

I use mat-button exclusively for clickable elements in my app. People often double-click buttons out of habit, which would trigger a double api call etc... it would be painstaking to add this debounce function to all mat-buttons in my code.

It would be good if I can have a global setting on which intelligently handles this.

### Use Case

Stop people from double clicking everything and getting weird results sometimes
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "fear(BUTTON): Ability to convert all double clicks on all mat-buttons (or clickable elements in general) to single click" (#26523)

Issues.Title: bug(TYPOGRAPHY): `.mat-typography` CSS class no longer works in v15
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

14

### Description

After upgrade to v15 `.mat-typography` CSS class no longer works when using customized theme.
The issue can be reproduced in the official demos. For example, content of [the "Dialog content" demo](https://material.angular.io/components/dialog/overview#dialog-content) has incorrect styling.

Related bug reports: #26184 #26351

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Define your theme [the recommended way](https://material.angular.io/guide/theming): [theme.scss](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-zi6bkz?file=src%2Ftheme.scss)
2. Try to add `.mat-typography` CSS class to some container in your app


### Expected Behavior

Material design styles are applied to the section using `.mat-typography`.

### Actual Behavior

Material design styles are not applied

### Environment

- Angular: 15.1.2
- CDK/Material: 15.1.2
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(TYPOGRAPHY): `.mat-typography` CSS class no longer works in v15" (#26524)

Issues.Title: bug(MatTab): Tooltip doesn't work on tabs (active & disabled); attaching tooltip on child element under mat-tab-label stopped working in v15
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

v14

### Description

Hi Team,

I'm aware of the tooltip not working on the disabled elements and there are 2 workarounds - using parent or child.
But in v15 the child workaround stopped working.

I was using the dynamic mat-tab-label template and had attached the tooltip to the child element which was working in v14 for both enabled & disabled states. After the upgrade, this child solution failed and I have replaced it with the parent solution for other elements like buttons but no luck for tabs.

Is there any workaround for tabs?

Use case - need to display the disabled reason on the element using the tooltip

Thanks.

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
- v14 - https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ewzvbb?file=src%2Fapp%2Ftab-group-basic-example.html 
- v15 - https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-hzuhyj-2stebd?file=src%2Fapp%2Ftab-group-basic-example.html


### Expected Behavior

The tooltip should be displayed for disabled tabs

### Actual Behavior

Tooltip stopped working on disabled tabs

### Environment

- Angular: v14 & v15
- CDK/Material: v14 & v15
- Browser(s):
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(MatTab): Tooltip doesn't work on tabs (active & disabled); attaching tooltip on child element under mat-tab-label stopped working in v15" (#26522)

Issues.Title: 'MatIconRegistry' does not appear to be an NgModule, Component, Directive, or Pipe class.
Issues.Body:
### Description

When added MatIconRegistry to Imports section of a freshly created app AppModule, I got error.

'MatIconRegistry' does not appear to be an NgModule, Component, Directive, or Pipe class.

### Actual Behavior

Here is the error message:

This likely means that the library (@angular/material/icon) which declares MatIconRegistry has not been processed correctly by ngcc, or is not compatible with Angular Ivy. Check if a newer version of the library is available, and update if so. Also consider checking with the library's authors to see if the library is expected to be compatible with Ivy.

### Environment

- Angular: 15.1.2
- CDK/Material: 15.1.1
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "'MatIconRegistry' does not appear to be an NgModule, Component, Directive, or Pipe class." (#26521)

Issues.Title: bug(google-maps): MapEventManager.destroy errors
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

MapEventManager.ngOnDestroy cause an error in console and freeze further usage of the app. 

When hiding the `<google-map *ngIf="visible">` component for the second time, the errors occours. It happens when leaving the current route too. 

**This happens when using a `<map-marker (mapDragend)=...>` with an(y) event listener.**

### Reproduction

Stackblitz : https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-nzdmma?file=src%2Fmain.ts,src%2Findex.html

Steps to reproduce by *ngIf :
1. Click "show/hide map" twice
2. -> error in console

![capture 2023-01-25 at 15 32 01](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5111137/215147457-82f2fce6-dd89-4f2e-b1bd-e7a27f3e9bef.png)

Steps to reproducte by using routing (not included in the stackblitz) : 
1) Navigate to listing
2) Navigate to detail 
3) Coming back to listing (history back button or home button)
4) Navigation to detail
5) Coming back to listing (history back button or home button)
6) -> same error as above

Line that errors : https://github.com/angular/components/blob/2f9a59a24c0464cbed7f54cbeb5cba73e6007715/src/google-maps/map-event-manager.ts#L32

### Expected Behavior

`<google-map>` should be able to be displayed and destroyed as many times as wanted without crashing.

### Actual Behavior

On second destroy, the MapEventManager calls .remove() on undefined object and cause an error in console.

https://github.com/angular/components/blob/2f9a59a24c0464cbed7f54cbeb5cba73e6007715/src/google-maps/map-event-manager.ts#L32

### Environment

- Angular: v14 & v15
- CDK/Material: v14 & v15
- Browser(s): firefox 108.0.1, brave 1.47.171, chrome 109.0.5414.119 (x86_64)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): MacOs 12.6.2
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(google-maps): MapEventManager.destroy errors" (#26514)

Issues.Title: fix(google-maps): error if API is initialized incorrectly
Issues.Body:
When the Google Maps API fails to initialize (e.g. when the API key is invalid), it returns dummy objects which return `undefined` from `addListener`, causing an error when the `MapEventManager` is destroyed.

These changes add a check to guard against those errors.

Fixes #26514.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(google-maps): error if API is initialized incorrectly" (#26520)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-chip-option): overflows the content of a chip not respecting the width of the parent container (in version 14 it worked)
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [x] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

14.2.7

### Description

the content of a chip overflows when the content is sufficiently long, overflowing the text 



![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/90850547/215234942-07eaef5c-223d-4f49-94b7-fc6adc8a29a3.png)
In this version works good 14.2.7





![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/90850547/215234950-64949194-fa69-403c-b62e-aa8152c9de0d.png)
But in this version the material not work good 15.1.2


### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Load a chip with enough text (even long enough to exceed the width of the parent container).
2. See what overflows in the current version of angular material 15.1.2


### Expected Behavior

The chip should cover the text by modifying its height, and covering all the text downwards without overflowing the parent container as it did in the angular 14.2.7 version.

### Actual Behavior

The text inside a chip in angular version 15.1.2 overflows.

### Environment

Issues.Title: help(mat-form-field matInpu): How to resize conponent?
Issues.Body:
### What are you trying to do?

What is the best way to resize mat-form-field input? I have several inputs in the application and each of them has a different size, is it possible to do this using mat.input-theme or mat-typography? In angular 13 you had to change the font-size.

### What troubleshooting steps have you tried?

I've tried overriding the scss classes, but that seems like a bad idea to me.

### Reproduction

```
<mat-form-field class="small-input" appearance="fill">
  <mat-label>Input</mat-label>
  <input matInput>
</mat-form-field>

<mat-form-field class="normal-input" appearance="fill">
  <mat-label>Input</mat-label>
  <input matInput>
</mat-form-field>

<mat-form-field class="big-input" appearance="fill">
  <mat-label>Input</mat-label>
  <input matInput>
</mat-form-field>

.small-input {
@include mat.what? // height 20px 

}

.big-input {
@include mat.what? // height 80px
}

```

### Environment

- Angular: 15
- CDK/Material: 15
- Browser(s): chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "help(mat-form-field matInpu): How to resize conponent?" (#26518)

Issues.Title: docs-bug(Button): Mention that the MDC buttons have a more specific selector for the button color
Issues.Body:
### Documentation Feedback

The MDC buttons have a more specific selector for the button color (there was a related issue https://github.com/angular/material.angular.io/pull/1164 in this project earlier).

However, at the moment the Guide [Migrating to MDC-based Angular Material Components](https://material.angular.io/guide/mdc-migration#button) misses this moment.

I propose to add mentioning of the above change into the guide.

### Affected documentation page

https://material.angular.io/guide/mdc-migration#button
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "docs-bug(Button): Mention that the MDC buttons have a more specific selector for the button color" (#26510)

Issues.Title: bug(expansion): expansion panel issue when nested inside tabs and using router reuse strategy
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

6

### Description

I was able to track this down to this PR:

https://github.com/angular/components/pull/13088

If I revert it everything is fine.

It appears that when switching to a different route and then back to the one that contains the Expansion panel, the animation state goes to `void` and thus sets `height: 0`, thus leaving the expansion panel in some desynced state.

This is likely related to one of these and is an upstream Angular bug:
https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/45516
https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/18847

### Reproduction

Repro at:

https://github.com/andreialecu/angular-reuse-material-bug

If you comment out these lines, it works properly:
https://github.com/andreialecu/angular-reuse-material-bug/blob/7d20d77e9723c6fbfa632105435830a9c82d4d38/src/app/component-b.ts#L20-L31



Video:

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/697707/214903123-486afc6b-0597-4132-8362-766f17cc9ed6.mp4




### Expected Behavior

The expansion panel should not be glitching.

### Actual Behavior

See video above. The panel transitions to a zombie `void` animation phase where it thinks it's expanded but it's actually hiding its contents.

### Environment

- Angular: 15
- CDK/Material: 15.1.2
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(expansion): expansion panel issue when nested inside tabs and using router reuse strategy" (#26509)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-stepper): failing basic accessibility rule
Issues.Body: ### Is this a regression? - [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version ### The previous version in which this bug was not present was _No response_ ### Description mat-stepper is creating the tabpanels INSIDE the tablist. This is semantically incorrect and fails an accessibility rule surrounding roles. The "tabs" should be in the tablist, not the tabpanels. ### Reproduction Steps to reproduce: 1. run accessibility testing (I use the Chrome AXE plugin) on the documentation site: https://material.angular.io/components/stepper/overview ### Expected Behavior The "tabs" should be in the tablist, the tabpanels should NOT be inside the tablist ### Actual Behavior mat-stepper is creating the tabpanels INSIDE the tablist. ### Environment - Angular: https://material.angular.io/components/stepper/overview - CDK/Material: 15.1.2 (tested back to 12 and that fails as well) - Browser(s): Chrome - Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): MacOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(mat-stepper): failing basic accessibility rule" (#26507)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-sort): sort arrow changes, but data is not sorted in the table
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

I do not know.

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

I do not know.

### Description

Data is not sorted in children's table when triggering the children's sorts to work in sync with the parent table's sort.


### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-yzr1r9-jtjxz6?file=src/app/table-sorting-example.ts
2. Click on the first 'Name' column on the top 2 times (sort should be active: 'name', direction: 'desc')
3. Verify that the parent table's rows are sorted correctly (in desc alphabetical order)
4. And also see that the children's table sort arrow points to the good direction
5. Also also see that the data is not sorted in the children's table (despite point 4.)
6. Verify that the children's data sorted only if the children's table header is clicked directly

Note: children's headers are not visible in the real use-case, it is visible now only for the demo.


### Expected Behavior

Data should be sorted in all tables.

### Actual Behavior

Data is not triggered to be sorted.

### Environment

- Angular: 14
- CDK/Material: 14
- Browser(s): Chrome latest
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows

See demo.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-sort): sort arrow changes, but data is not sorted in the table" (#26506)
